metadata.title: Dealing with the Fuzziness of Human Reasoning

sections.text: In this paper, we construct a blurred model of the thought process that, by calculating the probabilities and possibilities of all possible profiles of individuals, gives a quantitative / qualitative view of their behavior during the above process. In this model, the main stages of human thought (imagination, visualization and idea generation) are presented as blurred subsets of a series of linguistic labels that characterize the performance of a person at each stage. Furthermore, using the coordinates of the focal point of the corresponding membership function diagram, we develop a method for measuring the thinking abilities of a group of individuals. In addition, we present a series of class experiments with groups of students of T. E. I. from Patras, Greece, which illustrate our results in practice. Keywords: Blurred sets and relationships, focal point, human thinking, problem solving.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and discussion
sections.text: The following conclusions can be drawn from the material presented in this essay: • The main phases of human thinking in order to arrive at a solution to a problem generally include imagination, visualization, and generation of ideas. The above phases are helpful in understanding the "ideal behavior" of the individual during the thought process. However, in real situations, things usually do not happen this way, since human cognition is used in general concepts that are inherently evaluated and therefore blurred. • In this essay, we constructed a blurred model of the thought process that, by calculating probabilities and possibilities of all possible profiles of the individual, gives a quantitative / qualitative view of their behavior during the process. In this model, the main phases of human thinking are presented as blurred subsets of linguistic labels that characterize the performance of a person at each stage. • Based on the above model and using the coordinates of the center of gravity of the respective member model, our group of thinking ability is also determined (i.e. we develop a method of measuring the individual's ability for a model).

metadata.abstractText: Reasoning, the most important human brain operation, is characterized by a degree of fuzziness. In the present paper we construct a fuzzy model for the reasoning process giving through the calculation of probabilities and possibilities of all possible individuals’ profiles a quantitative/qualitative view of their behaviour during the above process. In this model the main stages of human reasoning (imagination, visualisation and generation of ideas) are represented as fuzzy subsets of a set of linguistic labels characterizing a person’s performance in each stage. Further, using the coordinates of the centre of gravity of the graph of the corresponding membership function we develop a method of measuring the reasoning skills of a group of individuals. We also present a number of classroom experiments with student groups’ of T. E. I. of Patras, Greece, illustrating our results in practice.
